title: How to Best Find a Partner? An Evaluation of Editing Approaches to Construct R2RML Mapping
segmentation: I'm Krista Pinky with flute operations, and this is a joint work with together with colleagues from the universities.

I'm talking about, well, basically more about how to get relational data into RDF data into semantic data using mappings in the language of our time L and about strategies about editing approaches on how to best achieve that.
Obviously, most data that we have out there is in relational databases.
It's the most common format for legacy data of all kind, and if we want to work with that data as RDF, we have to convert it.
And this is something we need mapping languages to achieve this goal.
Uh, the most reason or one of the most recent ones is armal, which is so far the only it's Donald in mapping relational data to RDF data.

Those tables, and then there's a corresponding ontology, which is the music ontology.

The mapping target is composed of a subject map as a fundamental building block.
Subject map is basically setting how the subject your eyes are being constructed and how and if, if and how they're timed.
And then there are any number of predicate object Maps that then say which predicates and appropriate values are added to each of those subjects that you have constructed before.

Then you would kind of start of those sketching at least the predicate object map subject, not the kind of data you want to get out in your ontology.
This is a bottom up approach, thinking from the from the ontology and we call it.

Then you would start at constructing views over the database that seem appropriate for you to get those data out and basically write the logical table first.

Each of those tasks was.
Consisted of two steps.
First of all, people had to map a concept.

As their background knowledge in databases versus ontologies was very different, we started with a self assessment how they rated their own skills in both fields.

And then we also assumed that task characteristics the different pitfalls and problems you had in those.

So what we observed first of all was that in fact, in the general case of all tasks, overall users, there was no big difference in the approaches, neither in terms of the time that it took them to complete the tasks nor in terms of the correctness of the mappings.
Are in terms of how the users rated the approaches in the end, so so we did not ask for them to rate the approaches, but we asked for them how.
Comfort ubly they felt with each of the tasks without explicitly hinting to which approach they were forced to be taken.
And so the difference is here are really small, and in particular in terms of relatively higher variance we have here.
It's no difference at all.
But then more Interestingly.
With the user background.
There was some difference.
So first of all, if we combine the expertise, little surprisingly, all approaches work better for people who are in general more skilled than others, so more skills, better results.
This is basically out of the same for both approaches.
Then, however.
If we look at just ontologies 'cause we would have assumed that people being more proficient at ontologies would do better in the ontology driven approach.

Differences?
Are in many cases not so big, but we could see a trend that.

Well, find out more precisely what exactly would be the influences here.

Depending on the circumstances, but none of the approaches that we looked at as a general champion in K and the meaning that it works better for all users or for all kinds of tasks.
That definitely ask dependencies on the user background, which were practically, and they also seem to be dependencies on task characteristics.

So when editors are being built, they should maybe offer both approaches, but ideally lead the user into using the appropriate one, but we don't know yet which one of those would be and future work that's comprises well to identify the task characteristics more clearly that make the difference and maybe also find out more about the users mindset.
